title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Pakistan before 1 January 2017?
preds:
Comment: 
Am moving forecast down from 1 to 0%. In order to achieve the 1'000 noncombatant civilian rate, the month of December would have to see **404 mass killings**. SATP's data going back to 2003 establish monthly numbers as high as 250-300 btw years 2007-2009.  When the "over a period of one year or less" is calculated remains an open question, along w/ whether SATP #s are indeed reliable. Both are EWP calls. However, both are reasonable benchmarks which lead me to my conclusion on a 0% probability. Here is why. 1. From South Asia Terrorism Portal ( SATP) data:
http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/Pakistan/database/casualties.htm As of 20/11/16 Fatalities in Terrorist Violence in Pakistan are: - ***596 Civilians***
- vs 940 ( for 2015)
- 61 for the month of November 2016 2. http://www.earlywarningproject.com/definitions
"...We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less. A noncombatant civilian is any person who is not a current member of a formal or irregular military organization and who does not pose an immediate threat to the life, physical safety, or property of other people. The reference to deliberate actionsdistinguishes mass killing from deaths caused by natural disasters, infectious diseases, the accidental killing of civilians during war, or the unanticipated consequences of other government policies. Generally, fatalities will be considered deliberate if they result from actions designed to compel or coerce civilian populations to change their behavior against their will, as long as the perpetrators could have reasonably expected that these actions  would result in widespread death among the affected populations. Examples of such actions include, but are not limited to: mass starvation, deaths resulting from the intentional confiscation or destruction of healthcare supplies, and deaths occurring during forced relocation or forced labor..."
Up 5% for awhile based on @crowden posts: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/379789
Down from 5% on 2 September, for passage of time.

Statistically there have been the lowest number of incidemts since 2008 however Q1 / Q2 have seen increasing fatalities from individual incidents. An upward trend towards sectarian violence is also evident as splinter terrorist groups switch towards more extremist ideologies targeting ethnic and religious minorities. government security forces are at odds with political groups such as MQM with a largely Shia demographic and as such do not offer similar levels of protective security.  Other factors such as increasing access  to Internet across the region amongst well educated but unemployed youth create ideal conditions for self radicalisation towards extremist terrorist groups. Geopolitical tensions between Pakistan and India have also increased along the kashmir line of control and whilst both militaries exchange cross border mortar engagements militant groups outside of governmental control are likely to exasperated the conflict for their own means provoking and over reaction from one or both of the two military border forces.
(no change) Should we seriously consider the Khan protests possibly triggering a reaction?

Comment: South Asia Terrorism Portal ( SATP) data on fatalities in terrorist violence in Pakistan THROUGH 23/10/17 show 532 civilians have lost their lives for 2016. For the month of OCTOBER 20 civilians has been registered as fatalities. (1)  Whether the tragic loss of this new terrorist attack resulting in sixty (60) deaths of POLICE CADETS falls within the parameters of a MASS KILLING definition is an open question of interpretation. (3) Early warning projects ( EWP) definition is as follows  "...We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less..." (2) On the one hand, LeJ certainly qualifies as an armed group taking deliberate action. On the other hand, the PROCEDURAL / DEFINITIONAL requirement includes, however, the action taken must result in the death of NONCOMBATANT CIVILIANS.  Thus, POLICE CADET trainees are (as grotesque and tragic to the surviving families such a characterization may carry) arguably NOT noncombatant civilians. That is, once taking on such new professional endeavor, these innocent young men are given another level of characterization other than "noncombatant civilians" even if they were merely "trainees". Moving from a civilian endeavor to a professional endeavor such as training within a police academy to take on new responsibilities carries a higher level of risk such as has occurred.  Thus, it is reasonable the above-mentioned tragedy does NOT fall within the parameters of EWP's mass killing definition. It remains THEIR call. NB: a broader more, common sense definition would include this being defined as a terrorist attack. Leaving EWP to define NONCOMBATANT civilians.    Additionally, ASSUMING the attack "would qualify"  under EWP's definition of mass killing, combining to reported October figure of 20 fatalities to an additional 60 ( & MORE from this attack that do not survive their serious injuries) provides a total number of at least 80 potentially rising for October or, for the entire the ENTIRE year to date - 592. Using SATP's data as a primary source, in order to achieve at least 1000 noncombatant civilians deaths of a period of a year or less would require over the next sixty (60) days through 31/12/16,  a total of 408 ADDITIONAL deaths or, a monthly rate of over 200. A monthly figure not seen for 2016 nor 2015. Higher month rates were indeed seen in 2013 and, less so in 2014. NB: SATP's source data. Conclusion: With Christine Lagarde in Pakistan today, PM Sharif is using the visit to talk up his progress on the economy & battle against terrorism. (A). The Army Chief General Raheel Sharif reappointment, extension or replacement coming up on Nawaz Sharif's agenda over the next week to ten days,  certainly is good  reason to follow this area closely. On the other hand, even assuming a BROADER interpretation of EWP's requirements, the remaining BENCHMARK HURDLE rate continues to justify a very low probability rating. (A) http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/pak-successfully-tackling-terror-economic-challenges-nawaz-sharif-3100521/
(1) http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/Pakistan/database/casualties.htm
(2) EWP mass killing definition - see GJ Q
(3) http://www.samaa.tv/pakistan/2016/10/gunmen-storm-police-academy-college-in-quetta/

The situation between Pakistan and India is explosive. The kashmir dispute is a contemporary issue that can affect both countries, but i don´t think that it could lead to a situation that would result in mass killing.  Here an important article about the dispute and the escalating tension. (http://www.the-american-interest.com/2016/09/22/the-explosive-india-pakistan-situation/)
Although there is only a couple months left in the year, Pakistan is a volatile country with many bad characters/groups lurking about set on creating mayhem.

36 Jan
9 Feb
101 March
1 Apr 199 deaths due to terror YTD.

Drop by 1 from 3 to 2%  Here is why. Comment: Death toll from Friday's Pakistan Mosque terrorist attack in the Mohmand Agency north of Peshawar has now risen to 38. (FN1) Early warning projects ( EWP) definition is as follows  "...We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less..." (2) Fatalities in TERRORIST VIOLENCE in Pakistan year to date  according to South Asia Terrorism Portal ( SATP)  shows CIVILIAN FATALITIES at 457 through 11/9/16. (3) EWP reserves the right to make the FINAL call on what constitutes a "mass killing" in line the specific # of deaths (>1000) & the time line resolution of this GJ Q 1/1/17. Thus, "definitional issues" on what constitutes an inclusion or exclusion  of mass killings btw EWP & SATP statistics., is "possible". This consideration noted, however, we now have slightly over 90 days before resolution date.  Definitional  issues aside, EVEN adding the 38 new deaths to the 457 SATP civilian fatalities number ( reliability issue)  provides a year to date TOTAL of 495. NOT one month, pursuant to SATP's monthly statistics shows a number above 126 ( March) for 2016. Therefore, in order to achieve the 1000 or more EWP definition, there must be an AVERAGE RATE more than 150 mass killings per month through resolution date 1/1//17. Or, of course, a one off terrible  "massacre" event. Such a SERIES OF EVENTS would constitute a dramatic rise this year and,  vs 2015 #s. It would SIGNAL a RETURN to the average +200 per month #s beginning from 2010 - 2013. (4) CONCLUSION: Pakistan is Pakistan so a more forward looking imaginative UNEXPECTED consequence analysis is necessary.  On the one hand, the #s paint a clear story. A large reduction from historic unstable times. Numbers, however,  are backward looking ! PM Sharif has been heating up the Kashmir controversy again &, will address the issue at the UN in NY this week. So, the facts will continue changing per the geopolitical situation w/in Pakistan, India and, notably PUSH to drive out Afghan refugees from Pakistan borders.(5). RETRIBUTION from Afghan Taliban elements is foreseeable event? A careful look IS necessary but, a SUM OF THE PARTS analysis of the above mentioned circumstantial evidence supports a low probability forecast of 2% for the time being, is justifiable. SOURCES ///
(1) http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/pakistan-mosque-bombing-death-toll-rises-to-36-3036277/
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-37387475: 
(2) http://www.earlywarningproject.com/definitions
(3) http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/Pakistan/database/casualties.htm
(4) http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/Pakistan/database/casualties.htm
(5) http://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2016/09/daily-chart-11?fsrc=scn%2Ftw%2Fte%2Fbl%2Fed%2Fpakistanisdrivingout15mafghanrefugees&%3Ffsrc%3Dscn%2F=tw%2Fdc

Coming down because the EWP project has a bizarre definition of targetted killing, which could mean existing civilian casualties don't count. It's a bit hard to understand, so reducing odds because of definition.

Reducing from 9% for passage of time. Although incidents continue, they don't appear likely to add up to mass killing. In todays news, http://tribune.com.pk/story/1174675/twin-blasts-rock-mardan-district-court/ (At least 13 killed, 52 wounded in suicide blast at Mardan district courts)
Up 60% on information from @Raahul_Kumar below. (It will be very interesting to see how EWP resolves or provides more feedback on these questions. I need to check their experts guess on Pakistan.)

"The cases of violence related deaths have decreased upto 40 percent across the country with 4,612 deaths this year as compared to 7,622 last year.
This was revealed in a report `State of Human Rights in 2015′ launched here Friday by Human Rights Commission of Pakistan (HRCP)."
http://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/pakistan/hrcp-report-2015-violence-related-deaths-decreases-upto-40-in-pakistan/ "According to the CRSS report, a total of 4,612 people died in 2015 as a direct result of violence, which is an average decrease of roughly 40% when compared to 7,622 violence related deaths in 2014."
http://tribune.com.pk/story/1020621/think-tank-reports-2015-witnessed-significant-decline-in-violence/ Still 4x higher than the 1 000 deaths required for mass killing. And the question does exclude one set of 1000 deaths as an existing mass killing, but there are already 3 000 violent deaths due to other armed groups.
Down 5% to be closer to the consensus.
Slight upward adjustment to 3%  based on combined feedback from @Khalid & @Sjens ( who... exhibits a special... understanding of this area per his explanation) so, I defer to his judgement on this Q.

332 civilian deaths reported till end July 2016. http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/pakistan/database/casualties.htm It will need 100+ fatalities every month from now to hit 1000. Unfortunately, there has been one such incident at Quetta in August already, with 94 dead, but in my opinion chances of that happening every month are low. The only other such incident this year was during March in Lahore.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-pakistan-blast-idUSKCN10J0I7?il=0
In general, one likes to see people do well at their chosen occupations.  However, if your chosen occupation is killing people, I am inclined to withhold approval.  Staying with 9%, but I should probably be bumping up about now.
At least 53 killed in bomb blast at Quetta hospital. Waiting to see what actors and motivation might be responsible for this atrocity before knee-jerking too much.

Keeping personal biases and hopes out of forecasting is a tough one. This question wants me to say 0% more out of hope and wishes than facts.  Unscientifically, based my discussions with Pakistani police officials (happen to have a couple of friends), the effort by the Police and the government to contain the terrorism and attacks are genuine and meaningful. Without specific knowledge of the actions, it is difficult to forecast. But reading the news accounts, the general public is standing up against the extremists instead of ignoring them.  A single episode of 1,000 or more people being killed is unlikely. (May be hope speaking than knowledge!).

(no change and apologies if this angle has been discussed before) I wonder if/how the "honor killings" would be counted by EWP?  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honour_killing_in_Pakistan If I am correct with my tentative guess that any generalized violence that isn't specifically not counted by the question parameters, these killings (at I believe a current reported rate of about 40 a month) plus others might suffice.

(no change for now) I’ve resigned myself to NOT getting any further clarification from EWP on what constitutes a mass killing. (Consequently, I’ve not elected to join the more recent questions.) Looking at part of the EWP definitions, I’d like to offer an opinion about two points related to this phrase: “targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less” 1. I now believe (but wouldn’t be surprised if EWP made a clarification that contradicted this) that the period related to any specific question starts when the question is introduced and runs through the end of CY 2016. (I believe the other ideas that it either looks back in a running period of a year or is the whole calendar year are wrong.) 2. There are at least two interpretations of which group(s) are targeted. A narrow interpretation is that whatever government (“in” tribe) forces there are target only a specific subset of the population. Then there is a broader interpretation that any significant deaths that are not combat related or otherwise proscribed would count (in the sense that those targeted are “outsiders” in some sense). I lean now toward accepting either, but probably put less weight on the latter as I think about a particular situation.

1.No elections next year so the government/opposition  does not need to make the citizens feel elated/threatened.
2.Every smart terrorist organization knows that the main reason for terrorist attacks is to cause chaos and gain limelight, and currently isis has summoned all the media attention, so any attacks in a third world terrorist sponsoring state would not bear anything fruitful.
3. The western world is currently countering isis so there would be lesser pressure on Pakistan to do anything, the pro Pakistan terrorists are funded by the same people who support isis too directly or indirectly. Therefore they too have work to do. 
5. The main motives behind attacks in USA and Europe are aimed at fracturing the bonds of the society and isolation of the Muslims minority for more active funding and participation in their cause. Pakistan is a sunni Muslim majority country and any attacks supported by these motives are futile as they will anyway get as much support as they want just  by spreading their message of jihad.
6. 1% just to be on the safe side cause the world is very random.
Update forecast, no change, passage of time.  The 1000 deaths of noncombatant civilians in a "new" episode continues to be an extremely high hurdle.
(no change) Who gets to decide where Kashmir belongs? (Slow night, but still an interesting angle.)

(no change) Two links to help clarify things until either GJO or @EarlyWarningProject can provide more global clarification regarding the relevant time frame(s). First is EWP’s answer on the GJO questions: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/281886 One can either interpret it to mean the clock started when the question opened or try to parse this quote “over the course of the year, without regard to calendar year.” Second is the web page for the EWP expert opinion pool: http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools (As you will note, the latter is for a calendar year. EWP tries to be clear that there are differences between the Expert Opinion Pool criteria and the GJO questions.) I’m updating my “understanding” so that I can find it easily and don’t have to guess: 1. The time frame for this episode begins 25 May 2016 and ends 31 December 2016. (Please feel free to explain the unexplainable.) 2. Official and unofficial violence against or by the main LeJ will be considered as an on-going conflict and not count. 3. Violence by other groups (plural) will count toward this question. Can be state or non-state, but excludes other countries' forces (i.e., a war perhaps something related to Indian forces and Kashmir). (As an aside it is NOT clear to me whether casualties related to peace-making or -keeping forces operating within Pakistan and special forces from another country operating within Pakistan would be considered.) 4. The criteria for mass killing does not need to be a single or even proximately related incident.

(no change) Here is one link I've relied on to confirm that the EWP questions are for the full calendar year 2016: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/244986 I interpret this as confirming that it is for a full calendar year (if not otherwise specified).

(no change) Following an exchange with @Tetbury http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/276761 Here is something I modified from an earlier post about the Turkey question. This is my understanding about the parameters. (As far as I can remember @EarlyWarningProject did not correct my summary related to Turkey.) 1. The time frame for this episode is the whole calendar year 2016. 2. Official and unofficial violence against or by the main LeJ will be considered as an on-going conflict and not count. 3. Violence by other groups (plural) will count toward this question. Can be state or non-state, but excludes other countries' forces (i.e., a war perhaps something related to Indian forces and Kashmir). (As an aside it is NOT clear to me whether casualties related to peace-making or -keeping forces operating within Pakistan and special forces from another country operating within Pakistan would be considered.) 4. The criteria for mass killing does not need to be a single or even proximately related incident. Thanks.
Renewed Taliban activity in Afghanistan seems to have taken pressure off northern areas of Pakistan. However, attacks on government military forces and police & academies still very likely.

There appear to have been at least 4 mass killings in Pakistan in 2016 in first 6 months of 2016., but the number killed is far below the EWP definition of a mass killing. So if a EWP mass killing takes place it will be an event on a different scale.
Down 10% on passage of time and http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/275786

I will go with the Expert Opinion Pool at 5%, because deaths from terrorist incidents in Pakistan have declined this year (and many of those may be connected to Lashkar-e-Jhangyi anyway). I'm actually not convinced that these things can be predicted with much certainty, though certain circumstances make mass killings more or less likely.

As ISIS continues to be driven out of Iraq and  Syria they will begin to look for a new area to set up in and Pakistan's tribal areas could potentially provide the perfect area to hide in. While currently held by the Taliban, ISIS could look into stealing new recruits from sympathizers, who despise the West. I believe that similar to what the Taliban and AL Qaeda have done the past few decades, ISL will look to utilizing suicide bombers inside Pakistan's borders, and could even potentially produce a couple fighters willing to shoot a large group near the area.
Isis/alquaeda needs to show it has staying v power & in fact is growing. Great recruitment tactics.
Mass killing seems to have become a custom.  There are so many parties and potential victims.  All it takes is a few jihadists or religious bigots to find an opportunity of which there are plenty.
Passage of time and there doesn't seem to be a new as defined by EWP killings. 1 000 is a high bar to hit. Could happen.
The reglious landscape together with the uncertainty in the region make this a hotbed for killings. I think it's likely but 1000 is a high number...
Down 5% to be closer to consensus.

Want to look like good partner for Hillary. 
If trump elected , odds up to 78

For those interested in trying to apply a statistical model to these type of events: Check out Ulfelder, Jay "Forecasting Onsets of Mass Killings", April 2012. The discussion presented in the beginning is worth the read. It involves determining what factors are crucial to predict these kinds of events and helps establish a baseline. Only 110 events from WWII -> 2012; with lesser frequency after the close of the Cold War, than before. (I am going to assume we say the end of the Cold war is 1989)  Just 'guesstimating' from that:  110 Events over 67 years leads to a 1.64 events per year. (110/67 = 1.64). However since post-1989 fewer incidents occur, I would split the 110 events into 88 prior to 1989; and 23 after.  
This gives a Naive probability of  2 a year from 1945-1989; and 1 a year from 1989-today.

Lowering my forecast based on information below:
The 2 year Zarb-e-Azb operation (1) by the Pakistani military to remove foreign and local militants appears to have been successful and is ongoing.    The operation had/s  political, defense and civilian support.
1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Zarb-e-Azb
Militant groups impacted include Tehrik -I-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU), East Turkistan Islamic Movement, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, al Qaeda, Jundallah & Haqqani network.      According to the article (2) more than 19,000 intelligence operations were carried out, with information obtained from each leading to additional actions.  Areas impacted included North Waziristan & Pakistan-Afghan border,   Balochistan and Karachi.  More than 1,200 terorists were arrested in Karachi and “an entire network of Afghan foreign and intelligence agency members (NDS) were apprehended in Balochistan (2.)
2: http://dailytimes.com.pk/pakistan/15-Jun-16/3500-terrorists-killed-500-soldiers-martyred-in-operations-dg-ispr
"During the operation ... 7591 IEDs, 35310 mortar bombs and rockets, 2481 land mines and suicide jackets were recovered. The troops seized about 253 tons of explosive which according to some calculations was enough for the terrorists to make ammunition and IEDs for 15 years.  During the two years operation, 3500 terrorists were killed and 992 of their hideouts were destroyed.” (3.)
3: http://www.brecorder.com/top-news/pakistan/303231-zarb-e-azb-to-continue-till-elimination-of-terrorism-gen-asim.html
If Ramadan passes w/o incident I drop to Zero. Till then I am at 20.
Even for a volatile region, one thousand deaths in a single incident (or series of related incidents) is a fairly high threshold.

I continue to think there won't be 1000 deaths of non-combatant civilians in " a new episode". However, when comparing my forecast with those I made for other countries with roughly the same population size, I realize I was too low. I have Bangladesh at 4% and Nigeria at 50%, whereas I assess Pakistan these days as somewhat above Bangladesh but quite a bit below Nigeria, judging by news reports from each country. There are on-going conflicts between the Pakistan army and various armed parties (separatists, Taliban etc) which won't count for this question. There is a high likelihood of terrorist attacks on civilians, especially various minority groups, but  "more info" states that attacks by the Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, a major perpetrator, won't count as "new" (Terrorist attacks or hate crimes by other radical sectarian outfits may count though many of them have links to the LeJ and could even be the same group operating under a different name. Will attacks by differently named groups count as different episodes or be clubbed together as one new episode? It could be the former if the attacks are aimed at different groups e.g. Ahmadi Muslims, Shia Muslims, Christians, etc).
The country can be likened to a powder keg, and it would not be surprising if a single incident takes more than 100 lives. However, short of a major assault, more casualties in a single incident seem unlikely, and such incidents are unlikely to occur frequently enough to reach a total of 1000 non combatant civilians in a new episode.
Up 5% to be above climbing consensus.

from 90% [1] to 1% [2] 
It is very polarized and i am absolutely clueless. 
In a country with population more than 199 085 847 ...someone would have said that a "deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less." it is very likely to happened. 
And now i am with my bias...from Montreal, from what i see in the movies...«Homeland, madame secretary, or last moments of Bin Laden», or Al-Jazzera. Pakistan doesn't seem to be a typical country of law and order like we used to think in political science courses. 
In this context, i probably have the same bias of the GoodJudgmentOpen organization. What it is considered a «noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group»? If a Religious group is targeted, i should consider it. 
I still thinking about it...and 50% is now my new evaluation. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/243658
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/244168

The political uncertainty in Pakistan is not decreasing and may in fact be increasing.  And with so many fanatical radicals in the country, I am fairly certain there will be another mass killing attack in Pakistan before 1 Janurary, 2017
After the fasting month, there will be another wave of violence to systematically destabilize the government.

My base was 51% provided by a weighted calculation i did based on http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/pakistan/database/casualties.htm. I then took into account that over the last 3 years there has been a steady decline in civilian deaths and that currently the totals for the past months are ~48% less then 2015, which was not a mass killing year. I did have to increase my forecast a little based on the threat of violence against schools/education facilities.
Pakistan is realizing that playing both sides is a dangerous game and will crack on Taliban. The Taliban or associated groups will retaliate.

The militants are losing support from the people and  extreme Koranic   interpretations are loosing following in Pakistan.
The militants will start to change their violent attacks mode of operation because the ultimate goal is not faith but power.

Pakistan is a hideous mess with elements in the military and the ISI supporting terrorists groups for decades as part of a foreign policy to thwart India and control Afghanistan. This pact with the devil has blown up in Pakistan's face as terrorist groups have turned on the benefactor. Expect more episode's of mass killings.
The Taliban need to show they are still a force to be reckoned with.

Decreasing forecast based on information that LJ and Tehrik-e Taliban Pakistan (TTP) are associated.   My previous link (1) described concerns regarding TTP attack on schools and this may still occur but would be excluded according the definition for this question.
1: http://dailytimes.com.pk/editorial/26-May-16/terror-alert-in-punjab

https://www.geo.tv/latest/106922-Pakistan-has-beaten-terrorists-Maleeha-Lodhi-says-at-Harvard-University-address - The headline is misleading as UN Ambassador Lodhi actually says "We have beaten BACK the dark forces of terrorism...We will defeat them (the terrorists) eventually - it's still a work in progress but we have come a long way,’" 
If arrest numbers of alleged terrorists are anything to go by, progress has indeed been made in the past few months, though these figures only apply to enemy terrorists of course, and not those with ties to the state. Lodhi may be correct in suggesting that peace in Afghanistan is the essential next step, but unless Pakistan is prepared to do more than whitewash its "alleged" sponsorship of terrorist groups in Afghanistan, Kashmir and beyond, real peace just ain't gonna happen. 
Wikipedia lists eight distinct terrorist events for 2016 - so far - with at least 146 fatalities. These numbers almost certainly lag well behind honor killings in the same period, an ongoing episode of mass killing if ever there was one. 
Keeping my forecast low at this stage. There is a high probability of further terrorist attacks, but a low probability that there will be a surge from a group with no links to LJ - accounting could prove tricky. Balochistan is a bit iffy, although anti-state violence across Pakistan was at a seven year low last year and I don't yet see signs of this reversing. http://www.dawn.com/news/1249317
Extremist forces are running amok,it's a matter of time before the Frankenstein attacks again

Pakistan has been a fascinating frontier  capital market investment over the past five year cycle. Would like to improve my political perspective in the area &, can't think of a better source than following @Khalid although, I expect to do my own independent work in the area - as w/ the other PM Nawaz Sharif GJ Q.
Taliban Splinter groups are likely to cause havoc

"We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a SPECIFIC GROUP, over a period of one year or less" "Typically, the perpetrators of mass killings target a DISCRETE GROUP. That group may be defined communally (e.g., ethnic or religious), politically (e.g., partisan or ideological), socio-economically (e.g., class or professional), or geographically (e.g., residents of specific villages or regions). Generally, unrelated executions by police or other state agents would not qualify as mass killing, but capital punishment directed against members of a specific political or communal group would." Following the pre-defined criteria, has Pakistan experienced mass killings >1,000 in one single year? Answer is unfortunately Yes, direct result of terrorist attacks, sectarian murders, attacks on minorities, nationalists waging war of independence in Baluchistan, ethnic targeted attacks and the worst suicide attacks. On the positive side, 2015-16 establishment has taken drastic steps to eliminate and reduce violence in Pakistan case in point extra judicial killing of LEJ top leadership, establishing military courts to deal with extremist that has led to hangings, ruthless crackdown in Karachi and Baluchistan against nationalist forces and military operation in N/S Waziristan.  http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/pakistan/database/bombblast.htm
According to data complied by the above for the period ending 19th May 2016, Pakistan has experienced 188 terror related deaths Going by Pakistan's recent history one would conclude 1,000 deaths to be a highly probable event and this may prove to be correct but such events do not have linear relationships. In all probability Pakistan will experience further terror related attacks but State action has to a great extent reduced terrorist space to take such actions. Since 188 (200) number already recorded, another 800 (80%) deaths over the next 7 months (approx. 210 days) required to meet the 1,000 mass killings by end of the year. LEJ eliminated, MQM, PPP neutralised in Karachi, Baluch insurgents capacity severely damaged over the last two years the only possible source of mass killings can come from TTP Pakistan, perpetrators of many suicide attacks, assault on state machinery including APS Peshawar.  Start conservative and monitor situation closely.
Especially as Trump gets closer to the presidency.  ISIS will want to goad him.

Based on the link provided by @Lullafterthrestorm (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/243642) civilian fatalities in Pakistan in 2015 totaled 940.  From January to April 2016 there were 237 fatalities that would be equivalent to 711 for 2016. Thanks to @Khalid @Sjens and @lullafterthestorm for very useful insight.
The expert opinion pool is at 5% (http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools/104).  I'm giving a higher estimate for early closure optimization.

Living in the country I'm biased, but I can't see 1000 fatalities occurring this year in a new episode, especially as actions attributed to the Lashkar e Jhangvi are excluded. EWP's expert opinion pool is at 5%.  Although the LeJ is excluded, there are several terrorist groups operating under different names which cooperate with each other, so it may be difficult to identify new perpetrators. The "Pakistani Taliban" could broadly encompass the LeJ as well as most of the others, and there is apparently a branch of the Islamic State too. The army is involved in separate conflicts in the provinces of Baluchistan and Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa, which may also count. Getting independent reports from those conflicts could be a problem, but most deaths there are likely to be from either the State's forces or armed groups, not "civilians". In the last year or two, there have been some major terrorist incidents (bombs or shootings) directed at minorities, mostly Shia Muslim sects but also some Christians, plus more focused targeting of secular liberals in the public eye. I will have to try and look up published figures to substantiate my initial reaction, but I don't think a total of 1000 or more mass killings is likely. Definition is important. There will be deaths because of the ready availability of guns, both licensed and unlicensed in a population of 200 million. For comparison, there were 372 mass shootings in the US in 2015, killing 475 people and wounding 1,870, according to the Mass Shooting Tracker, which catalogues such incidents. A mass shooting is defined as a single shooting incident which kills or injures four or more people, including the assailant. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-34996604
Generally, people who habitually carry weapons in Pakistan are much more ready to use them to settle petty disputes, so there will probably be rather more "mass shootings" than in the US. However, I'm assuming that "mass killings" are different from "mass shootings" and need to be specifically targeted at distinctly identifiable and otherwise unarmed and peaceful sections of civil society.

So far, I have tried to steer clear of the mass killing questions because they are simply very very sad questions. However, with Pakistan's name cropping up, I want to pay attention to this one. Why? Because India is neighbors with Pakistan, we share history, and more generally speaking, the people I. Pakistan face terror as well. Just as we do. Most of it is state sponsored - there or here, or so I believe. Insinuations aside, it is bloody sad - sorry for using that expletive. Especially for us common people.  Anyway, looking towards just data. Take a look at this: 
http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/pakistan/database/casualties.htm
Of the last 13 years, 8 have seen >1000 civilian casualties thanks to terrorist attacks (2016 excluded). That's a high number to begin with. Fortunately, first five months of 2016 have seen numerically low numbers. That said, the statistical likelihood is high - quite high. I will use 8/13 as the lower base probability, and use 4/5 as the higher base probability (4 out of last 5 years), and pick a number in middle as the starting point. So, 71%.
